intro: Coleus herbaceus, commonly known as the horse mint or wild mint, is a flowering plant native to Europe, North Africa, and parts of Asia. It is characterized by its square stems, opposite leaves, and clusters of small, fragrant flowers that range in color from white to purple. The plant typically grows in moist, shady environments and is often found in meadows and along stream banks. Its leaves are often used in traditional medicine for their antiseptic and digestive properties. Coleus herbaceus is also valued in horticulture for its ornamental value and ability to thrive in a variety of soil conditions.
